Explanation of predictions
For a given patient: (i) the mean error of his features (ii) his radius (iii) and his texture (iv) (v) describe the features most influential for the prediction. The 'best' radius and texture were the ones that predicted the best. For a class, the 'top' of 'probability' is the feature that has the highest impact. That is, a feature can influence the decision of a model as much as a lot more than a single observation. In our example, there are three features, and the probability of classifying a person as 'class 1' with the three best features is 0, 0 and 0 for person 1, 2 and 3, respectively. Therefore, person 3 has a probability 0 of being classified as class '1' and a higher probability than the other two.

I have been able to reproduce your dataset. Here is a link to the github repository for the code. https://github.com/jasonreggio/Lime.js/tree/master/brea...

This is an RTF file, containing a single patient (with a line at the end). The first line of the file is the name of your dataset, followed by the description of each feature. This description should be in the format: [Feature description]

If the patient was a member of class 1, this may be explained as follows: the 'average' radius is less than the threshold. The model may then fail to predict the correct class because of this. Please also explain why this was not predicted in other patients. 
For the LIME model, the best model was trained on the training data and the test data, which include both patients and non-patients. Therefore, to test the performance of the classifier, a test set must be generated for each patient in the original training set. To achieve this, randomly select a small proportion of patients from each class, calculate the mean and standard deviation of all patient features, and select the subset that has the smallest standard deviations. We then take the feature vector for the selected subset, re-train the entire LASSO model using the new data only, run the prediction on this new set, repeat. This process is repeated until all the patients are used in training. It is important to note that this process only selects a subset of features that will be used to train the final classifiers. These features may not necessarily be the ones that are most important for class prediction. For example, there may only be a few features important

UPDATE: It seems like the LIME model is a good tool for identifying features that influence the prediction, but it doesn't account for the fact that the classifier can't predict classes that are not the one that has the biggest impact. 
This is because LISREL is used to estimate the proportion of the variance that each feature explains, and this is then used by the linear model to predict the target class (0 is the expected class). It doesn’t account, however, for that model‘s ability to distinguish classes with very different proportions of variance. For example, LISOREL may not be able to classify a class with 50% of its variance explained by a feature that only explains 15% or less of that class“s variance, if the feature has very small coefficients. This means that LILR would not predict a 0 if it had a different variance than the 0 it actually had. You might have heard of 'black box' models, which have no clear explanation of what they do. This is not a black box model, since it doesn't have any clear knowledge of how the system works. It might take some time to understand how it works, and in the end, there might not be any explanation.
